Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical

A goal of materials research is to make responsive, biocompatible materials that can respond uniquely to environmental conditions and also be targeted to specific sites in the body. The development of carriers that can specifically target sites of disease would increase the efficacy of treatments and reduce toxic side effects of drugs delivered systemically. Nano-materials, such as spherical micelles and vesicles, can be used to carry large payloads of drugs and imaging agents. For all of the promise of targeted drug delivery, there are relatively nanomaterials that afford robust, targeted delivery while being responsive to environmental conditions. To meet this significant need, the PI's goal is to make a class of nanocarriers, made from a naturally occurring plant protein called oleosin, that can target specific sites, be turned on for drug delivery only in specific locations, and have reduced immunogenicity. The PI will introduce responsive domains into the protein using recombinant biotechnology, and demonstrate how carriers made of the protein can bind to sites of inflammation using a flow chamber lined with endothelial cells, the cells which line blood vessels.
This work will also impact the lives of students who are trained in the PI's laboratory. The graduate students who work on this project will be trained in the most current techniques in materials science, and be prepared for careers in scientific research. In addition, the PI will continue to run a highly successful summer program to introduce and encourage talented high school students to pursue careers in science and engineering.

Technical

This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Pennsylvania is to engineer an amphiphilic plant protein, oleosin, to make targeted, responsive nanocarriers for drug delivery and imaging. Because oleosin is made recombinantly, we can embed designer functionality within these vesicles using the tools of molecular biology. The resulting investigation will lead to a new class of responsive, bio-inspired materials with enormous flexibility for targeted delivery. The PI hypothesize that large stretches of oleosin can be replaced with domains from other proteins, preserving the amphilicity and self-assembly of the molecules, but allowing the design of new materials. One strategy will be to embed protease cleavable domains into materials that allow for environmental proteases to trigger the binding of nano-materials, or the release of drugs they are carrying after binding. A second strategy will be to incorporate domains from human intrinsically disordered proteins into oleosin, which will allow us to make humanized oleosins. The PI will study how the length, number and type of IDP affects the assembly of the nanocarrier and reduces its immunogenicity. The PI will demonstrate how these materials can be used to deliver drugs specifically to inflammatory sites using activated endothelial cells in a flow chamber, targeting the endothelial surface molecule E-selectin. In the process, graduate students will be educate in cutting edge methods for making and testing the activity of recombinant proteins, and introduce high school students to research at the university level and encourage them to pursue careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have engineered a naturally occuring protein called oleosin using the tools of of molecular biology, with the goal to make novel materials that can be used to treat disease or can be used for technological applications, such as serve as concentated reactors. The intellectual merit of this endeavor is that we can make materials that self assemble from designer proteins with absolute precision to target sites of disease.

Oleosin is a protein originally derived from plants, and it acts as a surfactant which can stabilize surfaces either between oil and water or between air and water. Because of this unique chemistry, oleosin can self-assemble into multi-molecular assemblies. Those assemblies can carry drugs or other useful agents.

Since oleosin is a protein, the "engineering" of oleosin is done at the level of DNA, and changes are cloned into plasmids and introduced into vectors. The proteins are produced by bacteria, and then purified.

We showed that we could make an oleosin that targeted a cell upon the action of a protease. A protease is a protein that cuts another protein at a protease cleavable domain. The strategy was to put a sequence that bound a cell surface receptor behind a protease cleavable domain, and then use a protese to activate the oleosin. We found that assemblies containing a cancer killing drug could be induced to bind to a breast cancer cell, but only in the presence of a protease. Other decorations, such as peptides that could penetrate cell membranes (called tat peptides), were also attached to the oleosins, and facilitated entry of drugs into targeted cells.

One major class of oleosin we made contained the amino acid cysteine. This amino acid does not naturally occur in oleosin. Cysteines are useful for attaching molecules and other active agents to oleosin, which would extend its utility as a carrier. We were able to insert cysteines at very precise locations in the backbone of oleosin using the tools of molecular biology. We found that when we added cysteine to oleosin, the oleosins assembled into micelles at low concentrations, but assembled into liquid condensates at high concentations. These assemblies are protein rich, liquid materials, and they have utility in concentrating molecules and accelerating enzymatic reactions. We found that the tendancy of oleosin to form liquid droplets depended on the position in oleosin where the cysteine was placed. The more distal (closer to the N-terminal end), the higher the tendancy for forming condensates. We hypothesized that the condensation was due to the oxidation of the cysteines in the oleosin (through the formation of disulfide bonds), and indeed, reducing agents were able to reverse the assembly. Thus, we were able to make a liquid coacervate that forms and dissolves as a result of oxidation and reduction (see accompanying image).

We also used oleosins to stabilize microbubbles for ultrasound imaging. Microbubbles of uniform size are useful for reducing the signal to noise in ultrasound imaging. However, to remain stable, a surfactant is needed. Polymeric surfactants, such as Pluronic, are insufficient to maintain stability, but it was found that the addition of oleosin to the surface of the bubble was sufficient to maintain stability. We studied the material strength of oleosin-coated bubbles using micropipette aspiration, and found the precise ratio of oleosin to Pluronic that makes the most stable bubbles. We the showed how one can use oleosin to stabilize bubbles into which methylene blue, a molecule used for photodynamic therapy (PDT), was introduced. Thus, by stabilizing bubbles with oleosin, we could make effective ultrasound agents and introduce other functionality, such as for PDT.

The broader impact of this work is that we now have a way to make designer self-assembled materials from oleosin, and can insert virtually any peptide chemistry to target a site of disease we wish.

The broader imapct with regard to outreach is that we were able to train two graduate students, three undergraduates, and six high school students as part of this project. One of the graduate students is on track for an academoic career, and is currently doing a postdoctoral study at Princeton in molecular biology. The six high school students participated in the Hammer lab summer program, in whch we train high school students to do research, and give a presentation on their results at the end of the six week project. Of the 6 students who participated in this project, 1 is attending Harvard, 2 attending Princeton adnd 3 are attending Penn. One of these students performed calculations on a model for how an immune cell (dendritic cell) crawls under directional signals. He completed the project in six weeks, wrote and submitted a paper as a first author. The paper was ultimately published in PloS Computrational Biology, a top open source biomodeling journal.
